title: Week 1
text: Upcoming deadlines

title: Week 1
text:
To do by next week

üìù Submit Technical Documentation Sections Outline
Submit by next class (1 PM on Wednesday 4/9).
Create a single Google doc with the following information:

Information for your executive summary about background, motivation, problem statement, objectives, and deliverables. Have each of these as a separate section for this draft
A detailed list of the sections (outline) your team will have in their Technical Documentation.

Specify who is the audience for each section or group of sections.
Discuss this with your advisor.

A timeline to completion for your Technical Documentation taking into account the capstone deadlines. Consider making a Gantt chart, but also a list of dates and deliverables is ok. Tips:

If you liked how we split up the DIP by sections per week, try implementing something similar.
Write your executive summary and abstract last, your project might evolve along the quarter.



It‚Äôs ok to use your DIP as a starting point. Here‚Äôs some examples for this assignment for reference.
Add your document to our shared folder TD Outlines and Timeline.



üóìÔ∏è Revise your project timeline

Revise the timeline you submitted in your DIP: are you on time to complete it?
Revise and discuss your updated timeline with your advisor.
Update your client on any significant changes.



üåü Read the class syllabus
Please read it and don‚Äôt hesitate to contact me if you have any questions!

title: Office Hours
text:
When: By appointment
Where: Carmen‚Äôs office (Bren Hall 4024) or Zoom
I‚Äôm here to help! Office hours are by appointment‚Äîjust send me a message via email or Slack, and we‚Äôll find a time that works for you or your team. Supporting each student and team with their capstone project is a top priority, so don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out. Looking forward to working with you!
Contact: e-mail (c_galazgarcia@ucsb.edu) or Slack




When: Mondays 9am-12pm, Tuesdays 2pm-5pm.
Where: Sandy‚Äôs office (Bren Hall 3017) or Zoom
Our class TA, Sandy Sum, is here to help!
Use this calendar to schedule a time that works for you.

Before your appointment, please fill out this form to share your question or problem.
Each team can book up to 45 minutes per week using the link above.
Appointments are available in 15-minute slots throughout the quarter.
Appointments outside of these times may be requested.
Drop by for quick questions‚Äîjust double-check that Sandy isn‚Äôt already in a scheduled appointment.

Contact: e-mail (sandysum@ucsb.edu) or Slack

title: Week 5
text:
üìï Class slides
üìñ Capstone Guidelines



1:00 - 1:10: Questions, check-in & upcoming assignments
1:10 - 2:30: Resolving a Conflict Workshop - Dr.¬†David Rasch, UCSB Associate Ombuds
2:30 - 2:35: BREAK
2:35 - 3:20: Testing brainstorm
3:20 - 3:25: BREAK
3:25 - 4:00: MEDS faculty reviews watch party









Due by 5pm on Friday 2/7

Incorporate the feedback you‚Äôve received so far.
Email your advisor and me with a link to you google doc. Be professional and remind them of the due date for feedback next Friday.
Make the most out of this revision: it‚Äôs great to request specific feedback from your advisor! Is there any section you‚Äôd particularly like their input on? Let them know in your message. You can also tag us in comments inside your document.
Page limit: The Design and Implementation plan should be limited to 5-10 single-spaced pages of written text. This page limit does not include the title page, table of contents, budget and justification, or references cited.





Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide
Slide 2: Brief overview of project‚Äôs products and deliverables (don‚Äôt include academic ones) and which ones you are currently working on.
Slide 3: An update or two on the progress you‚Äôve made on the deliverables. Include code, graphs, or figures your team has generated. Explain how this work will integrate with or is a step towards your deliverable.
Slide 4: Next steps.

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next class. Add slides to Week 6 - Flash talks.
Focus on:

Switching ‚ÄúShiny app‚Äù for ‚Äúinteractive web app‚Äù or ‚Äúdashboard‚Äù (all documents)
Avoiding big blocks of text + big enough font size
Clearly explaining the figures you feature and adding references and provenance where appropriate. Check how to talk about your figures.
Project your voice + LOOK AT YOUR AUDIENCE (i.e.¬†don‚Äôt read off your slides all the time)
Ask fo questions from the audience at the end
Practice and time it!




We‚Äôll have 1-1 in-person meetings February 6-12 to check how everything is going. Please book a 10-minute slot to meet on my calendar. Meetings will take place at my office BH 4424.




Context: your Team Management Plan + DIP draft submissions + flashtalks, and the feedback you received.
Add this item to the agenda for your next team meeting:
Discuss what went well and and what could be better:

‚ú®How will your team improve?‚ú®
Is your team delivering high-quality, timely work?
Do you need to re-read the capstone guidelines?
Should you seek more feedback or guidance from your client/advisor?
Should you be more proactive in proposing solutions or product details?
Does your team need to share work earlier so everyone can revise?
Do you need to establish new expectations or ground rules in your team management plan?

title: Week 6
text:
üìï Class slides
üìó Faculty Reviews presentation slides
üìò Style guidelines for your Faculty Review presentation
üìô Ten Ways to Improve Presentations - Dr.¬†Alex Phillips
üìñ Capstone Guidelines



1:00 - 1:10 : Questions, check-in, & upcoming assignments
1:10 - 1:55 : Flash presentations
1:55 - 2:00: BREAK
2:00 - 3:30: Public Speaking Workshop - Dr.¬†Alex Phillips, Asst. Teaching Professor
3:30 - 3:35: BREAK
3:35 - 4:00: Faculty Review Logistics - Jamie Montgomery, MEDS Coordinator










Read the rubric for faculty reviews.
üí•Read these guidelines for your presentationüí•
Decide with your team what preliminary results, progress, or prototype you will include in your presentation
Put together a complete presentation deck following Alex‚Äôs presentation, point 6. It‚Äôs ok if you add stand-in figures for prototypes or preliminary results for now. Focus on the story line.
Discuss your draft slides with your faculty advisor.
Decide who will be presenting in faculty review (and who in public final presentation). Every person in the team should be ready to present if needed.
Add your draft to our shared drive and be ready to do a formal mock presentation next week!





If you have already received feedback from your advisor:

discuss feedback with your team
start working on updating your draft
contact advisors or clients for clarification and share suggestions, and reply to comments within the document as needed. Remember to always do your research and discuss with your team first!





The class will be divided in two blocks from 1:00 to 2:30 and from 2:30 to 4:00. Each team will present and provide feedback to other teams as follows:

Your theam should work on their project outside of their ‚Äúpresentation block‚Äù. The following rooms are reserved for you so you have a dedicated workspace during our usual class time. You‚Äôre welcome to use other places to work.

title: Week 3
text:
üíªü§ì REMINDER: Dive into your data and start coding!



Don‚Äôt wait for your DIP planning to be finalized- jump into coding and exploring your data now! While writing the DIP, keep actively engaging with your data, running preliminary analyses, and coming up with questions. Divide tasks among team members so you can make progress on multiple fronts.
‚ú®You got this!‚ú®




üìï Class slides
üìñ Capstone Guidelines



1:00 - 1:10 : Questions & check-in
1:10 - 1:20: Upcoming assignments
1:20 - 1:55: GitHub organization & projects
1:55 - 2:00: BREAK
2:00 - 2:55: DIP Solution Design / Check-ins with groups
2:55 - 3:00: BREAK
3:00 - 3:45: DIP Timelines & Milestones / Check-ins with groups
3:45 - 4:00: ABT elevator pitch









Draft of DIP Solution Design section, including Approach, Methods, and Research Data
Include your workflow diagram draft (a screenshot is ok). In your final DIP this should become a finalized figure with an overview of your project‚Äôs workflow. Add these sections to your DIP draft in the DIP drafts shared folder.
There might be details, questions, or even gaps about how you‚Äôll create your deliverables. Start filling those in. First step is always to research, brainstorm, and clarify with your team. Then, as needed, reach out to your advisor or client with questions or options.

Draft of DIP Timeline & Milestones
Include a Gantt Chart to visualize represent your project‚Äôs timeline. Some Gantt chart resources from Casey O‚ÄôHara. You can also make a nice looking one in Google sheets.
Timeline should include client‚Äôs and academic deliverables, and appropriate intermediate deliverables leading to the project‚Äôs completion
Add these sections to your DIP draft in the DIP drafts shared folder.

Research Data Services Questionnaire
Next week, each team will meet independently with the Research Data Services (RDS) team from the UCSB Library to help you plan your Data Management Plan.
Complete the following tasks in preparation for this meeting:

Read the Data Management Plan section of the MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines (1 page)
Answer this questionnaire prepared by RDS. This is an informal document, short answers are ok. If a question is not relevant you can skip it or write a short explanation why this does not apply.
Add your answered questionnaire to the ‚ÄúDRP meeting questionnaire‚Äù shared folder by Tuesday 1/28.
Come prepared with questions about data management and archival for your project.





Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide (see template)
Slide 2: Your ABT elevator pitch telling us what your project is about (30 seconds max)

Your ABT slide should look like the in-class examples: include ‚Äúand‚Äù, ‚Äúbut‚Äù, ‚Äútherefore‚Äù
Audience for ABT pitch: general audience (think anyone at Bren)

Slide 3: Brief overview of project‚Äôs products and deliverables
Slide 4: Approach and methods draft diagram

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next class.
Add slides to Week 4 - Flash talks before class.
Focus on:

Avoiding big blocks of text.
Make sure font is not too small.
Seamless transitions between sections, clear, and precise speech.
Practice and time it!
Listen for every qualifier you use. ‚ÄúKind of‚Äù ‚Äúsort of‚Äù ‚ÄúI guess.‚Äù Avoid these!
When describing your workflow diagram, practice curious statements. Instead of ‚ÄúWe have no idea how we‚Äôre going to do this part,‚Äù what can you say?
Project your voice!
Ask for questions at the end of the presentation





Update:

Your GitHub organization‚Äôs landing page to include the project summary you submitted a on week 2. Delete all the repositories, issues, and projects from this week‚Äôs demo sessions.
If your team plans to use GitHub issues, milestones, and projects to track progress or allocate tasks, update your team management plan to include these.

title: Week 1
text:
üìï Class slides
üìó TA Office Hours Logistics - Sandy Sum - Sandy Sum, EDS 411 TA & Bren Ph.D.¬†Candidate
üìò Client Relations Presentation - Miya Scheble, MEDS Career Development Program Manager
üìñ Capstone Guidelines



1:00 - 2:00 : Overview of EDS 411, Capstone Project, and DIP
2:00 - 2:30: Client relations workshop - Miya Scheble, Bren School
2:30 - 2:35: BREAK
2:35 - 3:00: Communication roles activity
3:00 - 3:10: BREAK
3:10 - 3:50: Capstone project summary
3:50 - 4:00: Checklist for next class









Goals for first client meeting (to be held before next class):
‚òëÔ∏è Clarify what the objectives are (if you have any questions - know what they are before the meeting)
‚òëÔ∏è Address any issue with accessing data (determine beforehand what these might be)
‚òëÔ∏è Find out who the audience for your product will be and if there will be people who can test it
Before meeting the client meeting, develop an agenda, including:

who will be the meeting facilitator/chair and who will take notes
agenda (with times)
list of clarifying questions you want to ask the client
any questions about the data - make sure you know how to access it
PRO TIP: use the agenda template provided during the Fall quarter.

After meeting: reflect with your team on how it went and what could be improved.




Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide

Slide 2: An ultra summarized slide covering what your project will do
Slide 3: A brief overview of the datasets you‚Äôll use
Slide 4: One graph showing exploratory visualization of your data

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next class Add slides to Week 2 - Flash talks.
Focus on:

Avoiding big blocks of text.
Seamless transitions between sections, clear, and precise speech.
Practice and time it!
Listen for every qualifier you use. ‚ÄúKind of‚Äù ‚Äúsort of‚Äù ‚ÄúI guess.‚Äù Avoid these!

Flash talks are the first steps in practicing for the faculty reviews.




Read the following resources:
‚òëÔ∏è MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines.
‚òëÔ∏è Sample DIPs*
‚òëÔ∏è Ten simple rules to cultivate belonging in collaborative data science research teams
Come prepared with questions about the guidelines and the sample DIPs. The ‚ÄúTen simple rules‚Ä¶‚Äù paper will give you a good background for your team management plan (we‚Äôll work on it next week).
*We have reworked the DIP this year to streamline it. So, the sample DIPs from previous years do not completely match the new DIP format. However they will still give you a good idea of the information that will go into it.




Submit by 5pm on Friday 1/17: Finalize your summary paragraph for Bren website, add to Capstone Summaries.  Your advisor must review your summary before submitting it.

title: Week 1
text:
1:00 - 2:00 : Overview of EDS 411, Capstone Project, and DIP
2:00 - 2:30: Client relations workshop - Miya Scheble, Bren School
2:30 - 2:35: BREAK

title: Week 1
text:
Goals for first client meeting (to be held before next class):
‚òëÔ∏è Clarify what the objectives are (if you have any questions - know what they are before the meeting)
‚òëÔ∏è Address any issue with accessing data (determine beforehand what these might be)
‚òëÔ∏è Find out who the audience for your product will be and if there will be people who can test it
Before meeting the client meeting, develop an agenda, including:

who will be the meeting facilitator/chair and who will take notes
agenda (with times)
list of clarifying questions you want to ask the client
any questions about the data - make sure you know how to access it
PRO TIP: use the agenda template provided during the Fall quarter.

After meeting: reflect with your team on how it went and what could be improved.




Prepare 4 slides covering:

Slide 1: A cover slide

Slide 2: An ultra summarized slide covering what your project will do
Slide 3: A brief overview of the datasets you‚Äôll use
Slide 4: One graph showing exploratory visualization of your data

Pick a person or two who are ready to do a 3 minute presentation next class Add slides to Week 2 - Flash talks.
Focus on:

Avoiding big blocks of text.
Seamless transitions between sections, clear, and precise speech.
Practice and time it!
Listen for every qualifier you use. ‚ÄúKind of‚Äù ‚Äúsort of‚Äù ‚ÄúI guess.‚Äù Avoid these!

Flash talks are the first steps in practicing for the faculty reviews.




Read the following resources:
‚òëÔ∏è MEDS Capstone Project Guidelines.
‚òëÔ∏è Sample DIPs*
‚òëÔ∏è Ten simple rules to cultivate belonging in collaborative data science research teams
Come prepared with questions about the guidelines and the sample DIPs. The ‚ÄúTen simple rules‚Ä¶‚Äù paper will give you a good background for your team management plan (we‚Äôll work on it next week).
*We have reworked the DIP this year to streamline it. So, the sample DIPs from previous years do not completely match the new DIP format. However they will still give you a good idea of the information that will go into it.




Submit by 5pm on Friday 1/17: Finalize your summary paragraph for Bren website, add to Capstone Summaries.  Your advisor must review your summary before submitting it.

title: Overview
text:
Welcome to the course materials for EDS 411A - MEDS Capstone! This course is part of the UCSB Masters in Environmental Data Science at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Mananagement.
In this website you will find the materials covered during lectures for the Winter 2024 term.



The goal of EDS 411A is to facilitate student learning, work, and progress on their MEDS Capstone project through lessons, activities, supervised and unsupervised project work, and peer review and feedback. Additionally, EDS 411A provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g.¬†presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations, team science, panel discussions, and conflict resolution).



Click here to view syllabus.



Carmen Galaz Garc√≠a
Pronouns: she/her/hers
E-mail: c_galazgarcia@ucsb.edu
Office hour: by appointmnet, Zoom or NCEAS classroom
Best way to contact me: e-mail, Slack



The following is our ideal calendar, the course content may be subject to change as the course progresses.

title: Week 7
text:
üìï Class slides
üìó Responding to questions slides - Dr.¬†Allison Horst
üìñ Capstone Guidelines



Today the class will be divided in two blocks from 1:00 to 2:30 and from 2:30 to 4:00. Each team will present and provide feedback to another teams as follows:

Your team should work on their project outside of their ‚Äúpresentation block‚Äù. Check last week‚Äôs slide to see the room(s) that are booked for your team.










I might send you some extra comments and feedback
Incorporate the feedback and streamline your presentation
Iterate with your faculty advisor
Practice makes perfect!

Add your slides to this shared folder before class.
Be sure to review the following resources when preparing your presentation:
üìó Faculty Reviews Logistics
üìò Style guidelines for your Faculty Review presentation
üìô Ten Ways to Improve Presentations - Dr.¬†Alex Phillips




Next week, we‚Äôll practice answering questions a bit more.

Review this presentation about best practices to answer questions about your presentation.
Identify 4 - 5 bins that you expect faculty review questions to fall into (e.g.¬†model selection, data management, statistical analyses). Write them down.
Decide who would be most appropriate to respond to questions in each bin.
Write down 2 - 3 questions in each bin that you might expect (and/or are afraid of getting) during your faculty review
Prepare, if necessary, any extra slides you might need during your Q&A






Updating your DIP. I might provide some feedback by the end of this week.
Getting your preliminary results or creating a prototype for review







DIP page limit



The Design and Implementation plan should be limited to 5-10 single-spaced pages of written text. This page limit does not include :

the title page,
table of contents,
budget and justification,
references cited,
timeline and milestones,
the team management plan.

The last two items not counting for the page limit is an update from the current capstone guidelines.








Reminder



Have you let clients / external advisors / others you want to invite know when your faculty review is?






Next class we will be at the Environmental Science Seminar Room 4016. It‚Äôs one floor above our usual classroom.
Again, the class will be divided in two blocks from 1:00 to 2:30 and from 2:30 to 4:00. Each team will present and provide feedback to other teams as follows:

Your theam should be in our usual classroom working on their project outside of their ‚Äúpresentation block‚Äù.

Coworking
Check-ins with groups










Due by end of 29/1
Copy your organization‚Äôs URL into this shared spreadsheet.

Your GitHub organization‚Äôs landing page to include the project summary you submitted a on week 2. Delete all the repositories, issues, and projects from this week‚Äôs demo sessions.
Make all members in your organization public members, so people can see your GitHub profiles when they visit your org.





Add the following updates to your DIP draft document:

Updates for all other sections you‚Äôve drafted so far: Resolve all comments
Title page, budget and budget justification, and references section
Draft of Data Management Plan and Documentation Plan sections due on Friday 2/7

Remember to always read the Capstone Guidelines first if you have questions about how to write any of the DIP sections!




Add this item to the agenda for your next meeting with your advisor or email them asking for their feedback:
Discuss ‚ÄúExpectations between students and advisor‚Äù in TMP If you are not sure how to bring this up try something like:

‚ÄúOur Team Management Plan must include a section about expectations between students and faculty advisor. We have included some of these expectations and would like to discuss them with you. We also want to integrate expectations you have about how our team will conduct its work in this project.‚Äù

If you have already checked these expectations with your advisor, great! You‚Äôre done.




We‚Äôll have 1-1 in-person meetings February 6-12 to check how everything is going. Please book a 10-minute slot to meet on my calendar. Meetings will take place at my office BH 4424.

text:

No need to ‚ÄúSend repository access to CP coordinator‚Äù



The previous deadlines outline contained an out-of-date instruction about ‚ÄúSending repository access to CP coordinator.‚Äù You don‚Äôt need to do anything! We needed it last year, but this year I have the URLs to all your GitHub orgs where you have your project‚Äôs code.
Thanks to the groups who brought this to my attention!
Carmen








Upload it to Box in PDF format with your Capstone Project short name (e.g., Seamissions Design and Implementation Plan.pdf).
Email to your faculty advisor and client: be professional and thank them for their involvement.






Each student must complete a Capstone Project Peer & Self Evaluation Form for Winter Quarter.
Upload your evaluation form to Box and save your document with your Capstone Project short name and your full name as the file name (e.g., SaferSeafood Carmen Galaz Garc√≠a).
You must also email your evaluation directly to your faculty advisor.





Please fill out the UCSB course survey (10 minutes): https://ucsb.bluera.com/ucsb

title: EDS 411: MEDS Capstone Courses
text:
Welcome to the course materials for MEDS Capstone Courses EDS 411A and EDS 411B! This course sequence is part of the UCSB Masters in Environmental Data Science at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Mananagement.
In this website you will find the materials covered during lectures for the 2024 Winter and Spring terms. This site will be under construction throughout the course.


The goal of MEDS Capstone Courses EDS 411A and EDS 411B is to facilitate student learning, work, and progress on their MEDS Capstone project through lessons, activities, supervised and unsupervised project work, and peer review and feedback. Additionally, these courses provides opportunities for professional and career development (e.g.¬†presentation skills, writing and editing, client relations, team science, panel discussions, and conflict resolution).




411A Syllabus




Carmen Galaz Garc√≠a (she/her/hers)
E-mail: c_galazgarcia@ucsb.edu
Best way to contact me: e-mail, Slack



Sandy Sum (she/her/hers)
E-mail: sandysum@ucsb.edu
Best way to contact me: e-mail / Slack
